title: How to React when a Coworker Is Fired

steps.title: Offer real support.
steps.content: Offer real support. Many people will feel the urge to ignore the situation or offer platitudes. Resist this. The last thing your colleague wants to hear is that their firing must have a silver lining or is somehow “for the best.” At the same time, though, don’t ignore the situation. They will appreciate positive words of sympathy or, even better, offers of concrete assistance. [1] X Research source Rather than telling your co-worker, “Don’t worry, you’ll get a great job soon,” try a something simple and empathetic. “I’m sorry” or “Let me know how I can help” is much better. [2] X Research source Make a real offer to help. Can you help their revamp their resume? Maybe they'd like you to give them a mock interview? Or would they just like to get together for coffee? This can make more of a difference than words. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Don’t make light of the situation.
steps.content: Don’t make light of the situation. While offering affirming words, avoid at all cost jokes, dark humor, or a response that minimizes the situation. Your co-worker has just been fired. They are probably distraught and possibly angry or in shock. One of the most unfeeling things you can do in this situation is to make light of it, because this could make it seem like their emotions don’t matter. Saying, “You’re lucky to get out of this dump,” for example, or joking about how much free time they'll have is tactless. [4] X Research source Respect the space, as well. Try to read the body language from them – you may see that they are having a hard emotional time. In that case, don’t pain them with a long conversation or press them to go out to lunch or other things. It's okay to try to help your coworker focus on the silver lining in the situation, as long as you don't minimize any stress or sadness they're feeling. For instance, you might say something like, "I'm so sorry that this happened to you, but I'm really glad that working there together gave us a chance to meet and become friends!"

steps.title: Don’t offer advice.
steps.content: Don’t offer advice. Another natural response to seeing a colleague fired is to want to “fix things.” Resist this urge, too. In a way, getting fired is like experiencing a death in the family. Your co-worker will too busy coming to terms with the loss to appreciate your opinion about how they should start up their own business or change fields. They will also not want your would-be advice about getting a better job. [5] X Research source Rather than saying, “You know, there’s lots of jobs in health care – maybe you can get one there,” keep it concrete and helpful. Try something like, “Let me know if I can do anything. I’d be happy to look over your resume or read your cover letters.” If your coworker asks you for advice about what they should do next, ask questions like, "What do you really care about?" and "Ideally, what do you want to spend the next few years working on?"

steps.title: Keep the conversation focused on them.
steps.content: Keep the conversation focused on them. Being empathetic requires you to give priority to another person’s feelings, and to listen to them. You are trying to offer emotional support to a co-worker and perhaps friend. Don’t make the conversation about you. Don’t recount a story about a time when you were fired and how you managed. Remain focused on them. Ask your co-worker questions like, “How are you doing? Are you alright?” Avoid sentences that start with I or my. For example, “Once when I got fired…” or “Once I used to work at Company Y…”

steps.title: Follow up when the time is right.
steps.content: Follow up when the time is right. Give your co-worker some time and space to come to terms with their firing before contacting them again. Try sending a short email – “Hi Jane. I’m really sorry that you left XYZ, Ltd. How are you doing? Please let me know if there is anything that I can do to help you.” [6] X Research source Make sure to be understanding and not prying. Don’t go into the reasons for their firing unless they bring it up.

steps.title: Avoid discussing the situation with your boss.
steps.content: Avoid discussing the situation with your boss. Unless they specifically bring it up, do not discuss your co-worker's firing with your boss until the dust has settled. This is probably a stressful time for them as well, and they will likely be busy planning the transition period before someone else is hired to take over the position. It may be hard, but hold your tongue.

steps.title: Avoid gossip.
steps.content: Avoid gossip. Sometimes you can foresee a firing – a co-worker has a history of poor performance, bad relations with co-workers, or has had a falling out with the boss. At other times, it can be completely unexpected. In either case, resist the gossip that will likely be swirling. Stay quiet and focus on your work if you hear that a co-worker has been fired. Don’t speculate at the water-cooler and don’t try to pry from anyone, your former co-worker, your office mates, or your boss. Moreover, don’t believe rumors that you may overhear.

steps.title: Let the dust settle.
steps.content: Let the dust settle. Don’t horn in on your former co-worker’s responsibilities too soon. Even if they had easier tasks, a nicer office, or better parking spot, don't be tempted to ask for these soon after their termination. Let things settle down. Your boss will likely have a plan for you and the co-worker’s replacement, and could see your haste as in very poor taste.

steps.title: Perform better and more reliably.
steps.content: Perform better and more reliably. Be careful, particularly if you sense that your co-worker’s firing may be the start of a round of layoffs. Evaluate your work. Are you meeting expectations? Are you a valuable employee or an expendable one? Even if the termination was isolated, focus on the work in front of you. A firing can cause chaos and place added work on everyone who remains. Try to be even more attentive to your tasks and to the quality of your work. Your boss will appreciate your performance. It may even pay off in a promotion in the long run. [7] X Research source
